SHORTPROSE.P:
MS was given the affectionate title of Mother Seacole by the soldiers in the Crimea. Her nickname in Panama, Aunty Seacole, she seems to have regarded less fondly, perhaps because it bore specifically racist connotations from the US context, along the lines of Aunt Jemima.
passim

CHRONPROSE.BIRTHPOSITION:
MS was born Mary Grant, in
Kingston, Jamaica , one of two children.

SHORTPROSE.P:
MS was a free-born Jamaican Creole, in the mixed-race sense of the term.
Creole originally meant a person born in a colony of parents from elsewhere, whether white or black. This and its secondary meanings were usually inflected by racial prejudice. She herself seems to have thoroughly absorbed the mid-Victorian notion of race as instilling predictable characteristics and behaviours, invoking it in the opening pages of her only publication to apply to the natives of Scotland, Jamaica, and Greece, although her narrative in many ways undermines the apparent fixity of racial categories. She emphasizes at the outset of her story her good Scotch blood and that her father was of an old Scotch family,
B [1] perhaps to establish unequivocally her white ancestry, but does so in the context of declaring herself a Creole. She invokes without endorsing it the
lazy Creole stereotype, noting that others have attributed to her Scotch blood (in good white Western fashion) her unceasing desire to be up and doing.
2
MS implicitly distinguishes herself from her black Creole mother by representing herself, often in the words of others, as
yellow .
34

MS's mother was a free black
doctress, or traditional healer, and boarding-house keeper in Kingston. MS credits her with having passed on a talent for herbal medicines.
xxviii
MS took over the boarding-house after her mother's death.

MS's father was a Scottish army officer stationed in Kingston, Jamaica.
xxvii

She had a brother named Edward, who became a hotelier and storekeeper in Panama.
490

Raised in the household of an old lady patroness alongside the old lady's grandchildren, MS gained from frequent contact with her mother a yearning for medical knowledge and practice which has never deserted me.
xxviii She trained herself first upon her doll, then animals, and finally herself.
2-3

By the age of twelve, MS was her mother's assistant in medical care of officers and their wives who were stationed near Kingston.
2

As a young woman, MS—who describes herself as indulging a longing to travel which will never leave me while I have health and vigour
4 —accompanied some relatives to England, where she experienced racism firsthand from streetboys in
London
. She lived there for a year, then returned after stocking up on Jamaican delicacies to sell, stayed again in England for a further two years, and was nearly shipwrecked on her return home. She also travelled to
New Providence in the Bahamas , and to
Haiti and
Cuba , often with a view to gain.
4-5

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Grant married Edwin Horatio Seacole (a godson of Lord Nelson), who died in 1844.

SHORTPROSE.P: The full emancipation of the slaves in Jamaica finally took place in 1838, during the years of MS's marriage. Though she and all those close to her were free already, this event must have made a practical difference in her life, and sharpened her perceptions of living in a racially stratified society.

Her mother died not long after her husband.
6

MS worked at her mother's boarding-house. With her husband she ran a store at
Black River Jamaica ,
5 and after her mother's death she owned and managed a hotel, which she then rebuilt after the great fire of 1843.
7

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
MS left Jamaica for a gold-prospecting town on the
Isthmus of Panama, in the country then called New Granada (the present-day Panama). She went there to visit her brother, who was not strong and needed care.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Her narrative describes the brutal conditions of travel and residence on the isthmus, which was frequented by travellers going to and from the California gold rush.
9

In
Panama , since her brother was a shopkeeper, she proceeded to set up her own establishment, having brought plentiful goods with her.
9, passim She also began her field training as nurse and
doctress during a cholera epidemic. An American doctor left the town, overwhelmed by its needs, and Seacole was left to care single-handedly for the sick. Three years later, back in Jamaica, she nursed the sick at her boarding-house during a yellow-fever epidemic, and was offered the job of supervising nursing services at
Up-Park Military Camp near Kingston
, the British military headquarters on the island.
8-9 490
The English
Uppark is a historic house in West Sussex.
.

MS stressed that she was self-supporting and independent by choice: it was from confidence in my own powers, and not at all from necessity, that I remained an unprotected female . . . . [o]ne of the hardest struggles of my life in Kingston was to resist the pressing candidates for the late Mr. Seacole's shoes.
8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
MS returned to
Jamaica after her several years in
Panama . She stayed there for some months before heading for
England with a brief stop in Panama to wrap up her affairs there.
59, 63

MS landed in
London
after her voyage from the
Caribbean , to pursue her goal of volunteering as a nurse in the Crimean War effort.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Her Wonderful Adventures attributes to pure racism the failure to take up her offer. She attempted unsuccessfully to meet with the Secretary-at-War, then with someone from the office of the Quartermaster General, then the Medical Department. She applied to a Mrs H. who was going to take a complement of nurses to the front, and was also rejected by someone associated with Florence Nightingale. She therefore resolved to open a hotel in Crimea independently (having already nursed at a boarding house), and sent advance notice of her plan to the troops at
Sebastopol
.
78-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
Doctress MS arrived at
Balaklava in the Crimea
, with the intention of nursing soldiers in the war.

SHORTPROSE.P:
En route, she stopped at Florence Nightingale's hospital at
Scutari
; her offer of assistance was declined, and she was put up for the night in the room of a washerwoman.
90-1

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
MS worked on the battlefields of
Crimea
, at times under fire, unlike other nurses who usually worked in hospitals some distance from the field.

SHORTPROSE.P:
As she was in the area unofficially, she did not have to work within the formal medical structure of the British Army, which would have required her to style herself a nurse. To support herself, she built the British Hotel at
Spring Hill, Balaklava
, where she worked, as well as in the field, to provide medical and other services for troops. The Hotel provided a store, a dispensary and sick bay, and a transport service. At a canteen for enlisted men and a mess hall for officers, she endeavoured to provide a taste of home.
140, 96 259 She charged officers for the services she rendered, even on the battlefield, but cared for enlisted men gratis.
125 490

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
Crimean war correspondent W. H. Russell praised MS in a dispatch as a kind and successful physician.
250

MS moved to
London
, to
14 Soho Square
, after the Crimean War ended. In her last years she lived both there and in
Jamaica .
xxxii 490

SHORTPROSE.P:
She notes without providing details that she detoured to see some other places on her journey back to England. Another of her London addresses was
147 George Street, W1
.
197

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
MS, back in
London
from the Crimean war, was declared bankrupt by a court. Her plight attracted several letters of support addressed to the editor of The Times.
After MS had been discharged from her bankruptcy and had scored a success as an author, a Grand Military Festival was held to raise funds for her.

SHORTPROSE.P:
When Balaclava was evacuated, she had been unable to sell her provisions at anything near what they had originally cost. In England, she attempted unsuccessfully with her business partner to set up a store at the military centre of
Aldershot in Hampshire
. The four-day musical benefit held for her at the
Royal Surrey Gardens in Kennington
involved nearly 1,000 performers but netted her only ¥228.
250-2 490

MS's work in the Crimea was driven by a passionate concern for the plight of the ordinary soldier. One memoir by a lieutenant describes her as beloved by the rank and file of the whole army.
249 From the time that she settled in England after the Crimean war, MS involved herself in the cause of war widows and orphans.
xxxiii

A bust of MS was sculpted by Henry Weekes in 1859. She had already been sketched, while in Crimea, by the war artist William Simpson. She was later the subject of another sculpture (by Count Gleichen). A remarkable photograph of her from a Crimean album is held by Winchester College.

In the 1870s MS developed a friendship with Alexandra (wife of Edward Prince of Wales), to whom she acted as unofficial masseuse though she was by this time in her late sixties.
xxxiii

Despite such unofficial attention, however, and although she was decorated for her service by the French, Turkish, and the English governments, MS was not granted the government pension she hints that she deserved.
194 xxxiii 252

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
MS died in prosperous circumstances. She had suffered an
apoplexy two weeks before this, and spent three days in a coma.

SCHOLARNOTE.P:
Her grave lies as she requested in the Roman Catholic section of
Kensal Green Cemetery in London
. Her estate amounted to more than ¥2,500.
